;在一个任何事情都可以政治化的时代，也许不可避免的是，约翰·费特曼后来成为共和党文化战争中的著名人物。这位来自宾夕法尼亚州的身材魁梧的民主党参议员在 2022 年竞选期间在竞选季节中风，此后他更喜欢穿着宽松的运动短裤和连帽衫组成的非正统制服，即使是在庄严的美国参议院大厅里也是如此。 ;上周末透露;之后，参议院多数党领袖;费特曼着装规范失败引发了关于美国的大问题深度衰退;”；“;是否约翰·费特曼真的想成为一名参议员吗？;”）缅因州参议员苏珊·柯林斯，;威胁;在参议院穿比基尼以示抗议。田纳西州参议员比尔·哈格蒂;指责民主党;拍手回应;：“我穿得像他的竞选活动。”到了周三，费特曼显然已经玩得太开心了，不想让这个故事就此结束。在一条看似旨在最大程度地发挥病毒影响力的推文中，Fetterman ;提出了;：“如果众议院的那些人停止试图关闭我们的政府，并全力支持乌克兰，”他发誓，“那么我将在参议院穿西装来拯救民主下周。” （根据 Dictionary.com 的说法，jagoff 是匹兹堡俚语，用来指“混蛋、白痴或任何令人恼火或不讨人喜欢的人。”）

;

;抛开可能是第一个的内容众所周知，美国参议员在一份官方声明中使用了该词，因此可以肯定地说，费特曼可能不必穿上那套衣服。但他确实说得有道理：华盛顿又到了愚蠢的季节，众议院中的各种虚无主义共和党人——费特曼的贾戈夫——在九月底资金耗尽时使国家走向政府关门。停止美国对乌克兰的军事援助是他们的核心诉求之一，而拜登政府提出的240亿美元补充拨款请求，以保持武器和援助的流动，现在已经陷入了政府关门之争。;

;无能的众议院议长凯文·麦卡锡(Kevin McCarthy)一直试图阻止他们，但效果明显不佳，以至于到了周中;政府关门不可避免;已成为华盛顿的传统观点，尽管共和党可能会付出政治代价。 “我们总是受到指责，”爱达荷州众议员迈克·辛普森抱怨道。但原因并不奇怪：倾向于推动;政府关门的是共和党人，而不是民主党人; 自从纽特·金里奇 (Newt Gingrich) 1995 年采用这一策略作为一种钝器工具，在华盛顿的常规支出斗争中取得进展以来。周三晚些时候，当麦卡锡在众议院共和党会议上对一项旨在赢得最右翼对手的预期新计划持乐观态度时，一个新问题很快出现了：唐纳德·特朗普。

;

;几个小时内，这位前任总统-总统——在他的领导下，2018年和2019年初发生了历史上最长的政府关门，最终特朗普没有实现他所寻求的任何目标——公开要求共和党人蔑视麦卡锡并继续前进。 “国会中的共和党人可以而且必须对狡猾的乔·拜登的武器化政府的各个方面进行撤资，” ;他说;。特朗普正面临司法部特别检察官杰克·史密斯提起的两起刑事案件，他像他所做的大多数事情一样，以明确的个人措辞来描述这场斗争：“这也是取消针对我和其他爱国者的政治起诉的最后机会”。对他来说，众议院共和党人寻求停止美国政府的运作只不过是他 2024 年重返办公室运动的延伸，并对那些试图追究他责任的人——他的政治禁卫军——进行报复。

;

;周四，麦卡锡的突破性进展受到了该党实际领导人的阻碍，他的反叛核心小组再次叛变，与民主党一起第二次投票否决了一项管理年度答辩会审议的规则。 - 拨款法案。 “这是一个全新的概念，个人只想烧毁整个地方，” ;议长随后告诉记者;。但是，不久之后，Punchbowl News 的记者 ;透露;麦卡锡正在考虑再次屈服，这次考虑从国防措施中取消任何与乌克兰相关的资金。

;

;政治就是对比。华盛顿最鲜明的对比之一是众议院共和党人对乌克兰资助的反对。国会山上许多特朗普最响亮的追随者越来越热衷于这一事业，因为民意调查显示，两党最初对援助的强烈支持正在减弱，而且;大多数共和党选民;现在反对继续资助战争。

;
;
;

;拜登总统已将支持乌克兰作为其任期内的标志性外交政策，确保国会批准超过四百五十亿美元的军事援助，并团结;北约;盟友反对弗拉基米尔·普京对其邻国发动的侵略战争。周二，拜登在联合国大会年度演讲中将对基辅的支持视为对国际秩序的基本考验：“如果我们允许乌克兰被瓜分”，;他说;，“任何国家的独立都是有保障的吗？”周四，他在白宫接待了乌克兰总统弗拉基米尔·泽连斯基。 “先生。总统，我们与你同在，我们将与你同在。”拜登承诺。

;

;拜登对泽伦斯基的坚定捍卫、对盟友的承诺以及对普京的反对是他对国际领导力最强烈的主张。更不用说与特朗普的强烈对比了。我们这么快就忘记了特朗普令人痛苦的;与泽伦斯基的会面; 2019年，这位年轻的乌克兰领导人坐在特朗普身边，像人质一样蠕动，尴尬地声称“没有人敦促”他调查拜登，而几小时后，特朗普公布了他与泽伦斯基臭名昭著的通话记录，显示他已经这样做了。 ？当他担任总统时，特朗普几乎不放过任何机会严厉斥责国家的盟友并赞扬其对手，并且 ;鹦鹉学舌;俄罗斯关于乌克兰的谈话要点。 2022 年入侵之后，他甚至称赞普京的战略“;天才;”。就在几天前，特朗普;再次陶醉于赞扬; 来自普京，他几乎支持这位前总统在 2024 年重返白宫的竞选活动。

;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;

;与此同时，本周在国会山，麦卡锡向他受特朗普启发的反乌克兰边缘低头——;七十名众议院共和党人;，或三分之一的共和党会议投票决定切断援助在今年夏天早些时候的一次投票中，;拒绝同意泽连斯基的请求; 在国会联席会议上发表讲话，或召集泽连斯基和所有众议院议员举行会议。麦卡锡声称，众议院正忙于支出谈判，考虑到国防拨款规则被否决后众议院一整天的尴尬混乱，这似乎是一个特别蹩脚的借口。对比再一次变得更加鲜明。

;

;在国会大厦的参议院一侧，共和党领袖米奇·麦康奈尔是乌克兰直言不讳的支持者，他和多数党领袖查克·舒默接待了泽伦斯基。在旧参议院会议厅举行的特别会议，乌克兰总统在会上收到了 ;两次起立鼓掌;。根据舒默的说法，泽连斯基以令人钦佩的简洁总结了当前华盛顿辩论的利害关系：“;如果我们得不到援助;，”他告诉参议员们，“我们就会输掉战争。”

;

;大多数经验丰富的人最近几周与我交谈过的希尔观察人士仍然相信，至少目前，对乌克兰的支持是存在的。更大的问题是美国的政治日程：2024 年即将到来，随之而来的是特朗普——或另一位采取亲普京路线的共和党人——重新掌权的前景。难怪克里姆林宫的老板如此密切关注。 ♦

;周一，加拿大总理贾斯汀·特鲁多指责印度政府在加拿大公民、锡克教分离主义者哈迪普·辛格·尼贾尔 (Hardeep Singh Nijjar) 于 6 月在不列颠哥伦比亚省萨里被枪杀。锡克教徒占印度人口的不到百分之二，但在西北旁遮普邦占多数。在过去的半个世纪中，争夺锡克教家园的斗争（通常被称为哈利斯坦运动）偶尔会演变为暴力，并遭到印度当局同样暴力的回应。但在外国领土上进行暗杀将构成针对锡克分裂分子的行动的严重升级。

;

;印度外交部否认与这起谋杀案有任何关系，但也表示加拿大对待恐怖主义的态度，它被称为自由放任，将“继续威胁印度的主权和领土完整”。特鲁多的指控恰逢印度总理纳伦德拉·莫迪试图将印度描绘成全球舞台上日益重要的参与者；用他的话说，这个时代标志着“世界第一次知道印度可以为自己表明立场”。这些指控也恰逢拜登政府普遍愿意忽视莫迪近十年总理任期内印度不断恶化的人权记录，部分原因是美国重视印度制衡中国的作用。

;

;谈到锡克教分裂主义的历史以及印度政府对此的反应，我最近与伦敦大学东方与非洲研究学院名誉教授古哈帕尔·辛格通了电话，他是许多有关印度次大陆的书籍的作者，其中包括“ ;锡克民族主义：从占主导地位的少数民族到民族-宗教侨民;。”在我们的谈话中，我们讨论了为什么印度政府如此关注锡克教分离主义、锡克教政治身份在西方的发展，以及西方政府是否采取了足够的措施来保护自己的公民。< /p>;

;;如何在加拿大等国家出现大型锡克教徒社区？;

;

;自十九世纪末以来，锡克教徒大量移居海外。作为英国帝国扩张的一部分，他们主要参与武装部队，后来作为警察加入安全部队。因此，无论帝国扩张到哪里，特别是在远东地区——中国、新加坡、斐济和马来西亚——以及东非，锡克教徒就到了那里。 1887 年维多利亚女王登基五十周年后，他们开始抵达北美，特别是太平洋海岸。从技术上讲，帝国公民有权在整个地区旅行和定居。从那时起，锡克教社区在不列颠哥伦比亚省、加利福尼亚州，当然还有英国有了重要的定居点，自十九世纪二十年代以来，锡克教社区就大量定居在那里，自第二次世界大战以来，人数更多。;

;;在锡克教徒迁移到世界不同地区的同时，印度旁遮普邦也有一个庞大的锡克教徒社区，该邦是印巴分治期间分裂成两半的两个邦之一。那里有一场争取某种独立的锡克教家园的运动。您能否谈谈该运动是如何开始的，以及它在印巴分治后的印度政治中扮演的角色？;

;
;
;

;在分治时，锡克教社区认为自己非常脆弱。这是英国旁遮普邦的一个小社区，人口不到总人口的 14%。锡克教徒试图提出各种计划来保持社区的团结，保持旁遮普的团结，但不幸的是，这没有实现，因为英国人想迅速退出印度和旁遮普。此后，印度的邦或省按照语言组织起来。锡克教领导层认为可以保护社区权利和身份的一种方式是为建立旁遮普语国家而开展活动。这在讲旁遮普语的印度教社区中引起了极大的痛苦和怨恨，他们选择印地语作为反对这一要求的方式。他们认为旁遮普语国家很大程度上是锡克教主导的国家。

;
;
;
;
;
;< /div>;
;
;

;经过大约二十年的竞选活动，这一要求于 1966 年得到承认，但很不情愿。 1973 年至 1984 年间，还开展了另一场运动，要求旁遮普邦获得更大的经济和政治自治权。最终，印度军队在 1984 年的蓝星行动中进入金庙。那是一段痛苦的时期，随后是长达十年的麻烦。

;

;;你能做到吗？详细谈谈这一事件，随后也是 1984 年印度总理英迪拉·甘地被暗杀，以及更广泛地谈谈锡克教自治的推动如何在某些情况下变得更加暴力？;

;

;1980年至1982年间，锡克教温和派领袖与英迪拉·甘地和印度国大党在德里进行了长时间的谈判。但双方未能就诉求达成一致，锡克教内部的激进分子逐渐增多。锡克教领导层战胜了较为温和的成员，导致印度政府和武装分子之间出现两极分化。最终，这一行动在“蓝星行动”中达到高潮，该行动旨在将锡克教武装分子赶出锡克教最神圣的圣地金庙，随后英迪拉·甘地于 1984 年 10 月被暗杀，德里近三千名锡克教徒被杀害在随后的强烈反对中。这导致印度武装部队进行了近十年的锡克教武装和反叛乱行动，保守估计，造成约三万人丧生。这些事件给旁遮普问题蒙上了长长的阴影，此后这个问题一直困扰着德里的所有政府。

;

;;印度政府什么时候开始如此担心锡克教徒在外国土地上倡导宗教信仰的问题？印度锡克教问题？;

;
;
;

;它一直在定期监控海外印度人的活动。它第一次专门开始注意到锡克教武装分子的活动是在七十年代初期，当时离开印度的锡克教政治领袖贾吉特·辛格·乔汉（Jagjit Singh Chohan），通常被称为卡利斯坦之父，为锡克教国家发起了一场堂吉诃德式的运动。 。更具体地说，是在 80 年代初，即 1980 年至 1984 年，当时印度政府，特别是国大党非常非常注重监视锡克教武装分子的活动。

;

;;在我们之前在采访开始时，您提到您有兴趣将锡克教徒与犹太社区进行比较。你这是什么意思？;

;

;嗯，你会发现这种比较是指锡克教徒身材矮小，他们有宗教信仰，而且他们的体型与锡克教徒大致相同。犹太社区。 [;全世界大约有 2500 万锡克教徒和 1500 万犹太人。;] 他们既是一个侨民，也是一个国家和一个种族，可以这样解读。他们是一个复杂的少数群体，通常只从宗教角度看待他们，但仅仅将他们视为一种虔诚的宗教群体，就忽视了群体更复杂的维度。他们为自治和自我治理的权利而奋斗，并作为少数群体在西方保障自己的身份权利。例如，英国的锡克教徒和犹太人是英格兰仅有的两个在 1976 年种族关系法案之后的法律诉讼中被承认为族裔群体的社区。;

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;
;
;< /div>;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;它退潮了和流动。在 1947 年之后的大部分时间里，锡克教家园的想法并没有多少人接受，但 1984 年发生的事情引发了针对印度政府的反应，这使得激进组织脱颖而出。当旁遮普邦的好战情绪消退时，这些团体对锡克教组织的控制也随之消失。因此，自两千世纪初以来，以及过去几十年的大部分时间里，对于大多数锡克教侨民来说，家园问题并不是最重要的问题。事实上，他们主要关注东道国问题，特别是在 9/11 事件之后，以及许多锡克教徒为目标，这些锡克教徒经常被认为是好战的伊斯兰教，尤其是在美国。

;

;近几年，由于该邦的经济危机以及印度农民抗议的影响，旁遮普邦的年轻人大量外流。 2020 年至 2021 年间，旁遮普邦尤其成为农民反对纳伦德拉·莫迪政府和印度人民党的抗议活动的焦点，后者希望放松对农业部门的管制。这种骚动在侨民中掀起了一股动员热潮，重新点燃了一些旧的战斗网络和本土政治。但总的来说，在我最近的工作中，我认为分离主义者所拥有的忠诚度不超过散居国外的锡克教徒的百分之二十五。这是最大和最乐观的估计。

;

;;有很多倾向于分享相同宗教信仰的社区进行政治斗争的例子。在这些斗争中最坚定的战士往往宣扬该宗教的非常严格的教义或愿景。推动锡克教家园的更暴力因素在多大程度上与对锡克教本身的严厉或严格解释有关？;

;

;Since ;Rishi Sunak; became Britain's Prime Minister, almost a year ago, in the middle of a national financial breakdown, his premiership has been defined by trying to make things go away. He wants inflation to halve. He wants the gigantic waiting lists for treatment on the National Health Service to shrink. He wants refugees to stop risking their lives by crossing the English Channel in unsafe inflatable boats. He wants to make ;the climate crisis; somebody else's problem. On Tuesday evening, the BBC reported that Sunak was preparing to either renounce, or soft-pedal, some of the country's most important policies to reduce its carbon emissions: a ban on the sale of new gas- and diesel-driven cars would slide to 2035, from 2030, while other plans to phase out gas-and-oil-fired boilers would be relaxed. In an unusual, late-night response to the leaked information, Sunak insisted that Britain was still committed to reaching “Net Zero by 2050 . 。 。 but doing so in a better, more proportionate way.”

;

;If Sunak's track record on climate is anything to go by, then “proportionate” means new licenses for oil-and-gas exploration in the North Sea; Britain's first new deep coal mine for thirty years, which was approved last December; and the scrapping of a range of incentives to improve home insulation or to switch to electric vehicles, which Sunak oversaw as ;Boris Johnson;'s Chancellor of the Exchequer. Sunak has never seemed to take the future of the planet seriously. Johnson, to give him his due, brought his customary, shallow bluster. In 2021, Johnson treated the ;COP;26 climate-change summit, in Glasgow, to the joys of his egomania and manic charm. In 2022, weeks after becoming Prime Minister, Sunak had to be shamed by party colleagues and international criticism into attending ;COP;27, in Sharm el-Sheikh, at all.

;

;Since Sunak took office, by default (there was no leadership contest, after the spontaneous political combustion of Prime Minister ;Liz Truss;), there has been a gradual, but angry, exodus of Conservative politicians or officials distressed by his administration's indifference to the climate crisis—an issue that commands a broad consensus among the British public. (According to the Office for National Statistics, a steady seventy-five per cent of Britons, over the age of sixteen, describe themselves as “very or somewhat” worried about climate change). In June, Lord Deben, the chairman of the UK's Climate Change Committee, an independent body that reports on the government's progress—or lack of—toward its climate commitments, warned Sunak that Britain had “lost its clear global climate leadership” and was falling behind the United States and Europe in its transition to a low-carbon economy. Deben is eighty-three and a former environment minister under ;Margaret Thatcher;. “Our children will not forgive us if we leave them a world of withering heat and devastating storms where sea level rises and extreme temperatures force millions to move because their countries are no longer habitable,” he wrote in a public letter to Sunak. “None of us can avoid our responsibility. Delay is not an option.”

;

;At first glance, Sunak's disregard for humanity's greatest political challenge is hard to fathom. Whatever damage it has done, looking after the environment and curbing greenhouse-gas emissions has figured into Conservative party policy as far back as the late eighties. In November, 1989, Thatcher, who trained as a research chemist, warned the United Nations General Assembly of the “insidious danger” of climate change and “the prospect of irretrievable damage to the atmosphere, to the oceans, to earth itself.” Sunak is a technocrat. His political brand, such as it is, is of a switched-on tech bro, scrolling his way through the ;Financial Times.; He is forty-three. He has an MBA from Stanford. He likes talking about AI

;
;
;

;As the news broke on Tuesday night of Sunak's retreat from the government's climate ambitions, it was possible to sense the shock of financial institutions, manufacturers, climate scientists, and fellow-Conservatives feeling abandoned by one of their own. “I just came out of a meeting where a chunk of the British economy was assured by ministers that net zero was a top priority and that policy stability was crucial for investors,” Emma Pinchbeck, the chief executive of Energy UK, which represents the country's energy industry, told the ;Guardian.; “Now this.” Lisa Brankin, the chair of Ford UK, which has invested more than five hundred million dollars in its British car plants to meet the 2030 phaseout of new gas- and diesel-driven cars, expressed her dismay: “Our business needs three things from the UK government: ambition, commitment and consistency. A relaxation of 2030 would undermine all three.”

;

;The most plausible explanation for Sunak's decision is that it is shameful political posturing. One of the depressing parts of trying to explain contemporary British politics is being honest about quite how small-minded and contingent it is. In July, the Conservatives narrowly won a by-election in Uxbridge and South Ruislip, Johnson's former parliamentary seat, in West London. Although the party had held Uxbridge for more than fifty years, it was a rare electoral success for Sunak. (The Conservatives are some twenty points behind in the opinion polls and have lost a slew of similar contests since he took office.) The win in suburban Uxbridge was put down to vigorous local campaigning against London's Ultra Low Emission Zone, a daily levy on people driving older, polluting cars, which has recently expanded to cover the whole city. Sunak faces a general election, most likely next spring, which he is expected to lose. Tapping into public unease about the short-term costs of decarbonizing the economy (rather than attempting to do anything about that) is now a wedge issue that the Tories hope to exploit against Keir Starmer's Labour Party, which is timid and easily spooked about such things. Sunak's more nihilistic right-wing colleagues have swung in eagerly behind the policy shift. “We are not going to save the planet by bankrupting the British people,” Suella Braverman, the Home Secretary and moving spirit behind the government's inhumane new policies toward refugees, said on Wednesday morning. Jacob Rees-Mogg, the sonorous Brexiteer who served, briefly, as Truss's Business Secretary, said that his constituents did not want to be poor and cold. Rees-Mogg, who has an estimated net worth of more than a hundred million pounds, described net zero as “a scheme of the élite.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Sunak had planned to give a speech explaining his more proportionate approach to the climate emergency later in the week. But the news cycle, like a warming ocean, or a wildfire, does not always conform to a politician's plans. Instead, he was bounced into an emergency meeting of his cabinet and an address, in Downing Street, on Wednesday afternoon. “We've stumbled into a consensus about the future of our country that no one seems to be happy with,” Sunak said, speaking from a lectern decorated with the slogan “Long-Term Decisions for a Brighter Future.”

;

;Sunak called for honesty about the costs of decarbonizing the economy and ruled out some scary-sounding policy ideas that nobody was seriously suggesting: punitively high taxes on air travel; compulsory carpooling; a special tax on meat. “This debate needs more clarity, not more emotion,” the Prime Minister said, not long after describing the UK—which in 2020 had higher carbon emissions per capita than France, Spain, or Sweden, and is Europe's second-largest extractor of fossil fuels—as “so far ahead of every country in the world.” Then he slipped in the good news: “We're going to ease the transition to electric vehicles,” along with the scrapping or dialling down of various other measures to improve the energy performance of Britain's generally old and poorly insulated housing stock. In the end, Sunak could argue that the changes aren't so dramatic. Delaying Britain's phaseout of gas- and diesel-driven cars to 2035 merely moves it out of the overachievers' club of countries such as Singapore and Norway and into the company of Germany, Canada, and the state of New York. But there was the whisper of moral abdication in his words as well. “When our share of global emissions is less than one per cent, how can it be right that British citizens are now being told to sacrifice even more than others?” Sunak asked. Why, for that matter, sacrifice anything at all? That has always been the shameless argument of rich, polluting nations in the politics of climate change, and Sunak did not shrink from it at all. He wants more time. We all do. It doesn't mean he is going to get it. ♦

;Technically, there are only four characters in Rebecca Gilman's “Swing State,” a melancholy new drama, now at the Minetta Lane. There's a retired guidance counsellor, Peg (Mary Beth Fisher); her troubled young neighbor, Ryan (Bubba Weiler); the local sheriff, Kris (Kirsten Fitzgerald); and Kris's niece and deferential new deputy, Dani (Anne E. Thompson). They all cause problems for one another, even as they try their clumsy best to offer help. But the fifth character—and the one we should really be worrying about—is Wisconsin. Is anyone doing anything for Wisconsin? In 2021, the swing state of the title is teetering, both socially and ecologically, and Gilman deposits us in that trembling landscape, even though her play takes place entirely indoors.

;

;Peg's sprawling house sits on more than forty acres of so-called remnant prairie, a rare sliver of the tallgrass Plains, an endangered ecosystem that dates back roughly ten thousand years. “There used to be millions and millions of acres of it, all down the middle of the country, but there's only about four per cent left now,” she tells Dani. Sheriff Kris hankers after the untilled property—she's dying to see it “put to good use” as productive cropland—but Peg is committed to protecting her wild remnant from the corn and soybean monocultures that threaten it on all sides. A biome doesn't necessarily obey boundary markers, however, and nitrates from huge farms are leaching into Peg's groundwater, as pesticides drip over her fence line.

;

;Prairies, though they appear simple, are miraculous beneath the soil—thanks to complex root masses that descend as deep as fifteen feet, they can survive grazing, fires, and drought. Peg, as played by the graceful Fisher, possesses that quality, too: her selfhood goes beyond what we see. She has been knocked sideways by the sudden death of her biologist husband, a year earlier, and, in her friendship with Ryan, who has recently finished a prison term for felony battery, it's unclear who needs the other more. (“All we do is apologize to each other. We got a weird relationship,” Ryan says to Dani, as he sticks a note on Peg's fridge.) Gilman sketches in a web of neighborly stewardship. But that social web, already weakened by the pandemic and vitriolic political division, begins to tear once Peg notices that she's missing some tools. When the police investigate, everything violently unravels.

;

;The director, Robert Falls, has brought his 2022 Goodman Theatre production to New York from Chicago; here, the show is produced by Audible, and will be released as an audio drama after its run. The ensemble's long process has polished some aspects of the production to a deep shine. Todd Rosenthal's farmhouse set is imaginatively detailed—we can see, on a high shelf, a jar of gumballs that Peg must have kept on hand in case her students dropped by—as is Eric Southern's lighting design, a series of gray skies outside and plucky little lamps inside, which reflects the characters' sense of embattled isolation.

;

;Among an experienced troupe, Weiler, as Ryan, is still settling into his part; he seems so bent on conveying “troubled youth” that he attacks the soup Peg makes for him as if he's never held a spoon. Fortunately, Fitzgerald and Thompson both do precise, naturalistic work with Gilman's delicately shaded dialogue, and manage to make the community just offstage seem populous and real. In the end, though, “Swing State” rests on Fisher's shoulders: she starred in the original production of Gilman's most famous play, “Spinning Into Butter,” from 1999, and this part was written for her. The production trusts her to hold our attention even as she's wandering in and out of rooms, alone. The play can be immensely moving when Peg lists her prairie's vanishing species—whip-poor-wills, nighthawks, chorus frogs—and we see her yearning to join them in oblivion.

;
;
;

;Gilman has written an intermissionless play whose events swell to a climax, but it's difficult, sometimes, to impose conventional action onto the abyss of her heroine's death urge and the spectre of the sixth mass extinction. For all her extraordinary subtleties of characterization, Gilman can be a bit conspicuous, as a plotter, when she tries to hurry things along. “Swing State” is the third play I've seen this year to use a panic attack or a stress-induced seizure as a dramaturgical accelerant. (The others were Christina Masciotti's “No Good Things Dwell in the Flesh” and Branden Jacobs-Jenkins's “The Comeuppance.”) It's certainly handy for a playwright to have a character whose response to a tense situation is to hyperventilate and get loud, but Ryan's breakdowns show us Gilman's craft too clearly. ;Here; is a turning point, they say. Crescendo ;here;.

;

;Still, “Swing State” is a model of structural restraint compared with Theresa Rebeck's tonally haywire “Dig,” which is busy shovelling itself into a hole uptown at the 59E59 Theatres. Rebeck also wants to use plants—their resilience, their need for space and care—as a metaphor, but this show is a mind-boggling misfire. Rebeck has written dozens of tartly observed social dramas; she has noted that she is “the most Broadway-produced female playwright of our time.” (Her fifth production there, “I Need That,” arrives later this fall.) In a prolific career that has included writing for a number of television shows, such as “NYPD Blue” and “Law & Order: Criminal Intent,” she created the catnip-for-musical-lovers dramedy “Smash.” Whether you're delighted by her other work or not, it's sturdy. It follows certain laws of cause and effect.

;

;But the characters in “Dig” run so counter to recognizable human behavior that they'll say and do anything. The play's title refers to the name of a plant shop, which some people onstage inexplicably seem to find confusing. “You don't actually know what kind of store that might be,” a customer says, even though she has, clearly, managed to figure it out. The shop's owner, Roger (Jeffrey Bean), claims at one point that he hadn't been selling flowering plants because he found them “too eager to please.”什么？ And, when Megan (Andrea Syglowski), the local pariah and the daughter of his only friend, tries to seduce Roger, she does so by haranguing him with a non sequitur. “You act like a virgin,” she says. No, he doesn't. And who says that?

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;We know two core things about Megan: she insists on telling the truth about her self-destructiveness to everyone she encounters (“This is totally my mandate,” she says, blaming her oversharing on AA), and she is tortured by guilt for having let her child die in an overheated car. When her evil ex-husband, Adam (David Mason), slinks in like a mustachio-twirling nineteenth-century villain—Rebeck, who also directs the play, makes sure the performances are visible from outer space—we discover that she has been lying about her culpability. But Megan's actions and even the first half of her scene with Adam don't make sense without that guilt. It's as if the actors, the characters, and the playwright herself are all finding out about the twist at the same time.

;

;I'm as capable as the next person of enjoying a play going cattywampus, but “Dig,” with its barmy melodrama and sickening, torn-from-the-headlines violence, eventually becomes repulsive. It's one thing to be lazy about researching what goes on in a plant store (it's not ;all; repotting and pruning), and quite another to be slapdash while staging the sexual assault of a blacked-out woman. Roger, whom Rebeck has chosen as her Do-Right hero amid a wilderness of wicked men, interrupts his onetime employee Everett (poor, poor Greg Keller) mid-attack, and accuses him of taking advantage of Megan's broken heart. Her heart? Instead of calling the cops or a doctor, let alone telling Megan what has happened to her when she asks the next morning, Roger shouts at her, then apologizes, then looks meaningfully at a fake African violet. “It can be saved,” he says. Oh, Roger, no. Maybe your phony plant is gonna make it—but that potted metaphor you're holding has been dead for around two hours. ♦

;The year was 1985, Ronald Reagan's Morning in America was in full swing, and the Minneapolis-based Replacements were making moves. Following a string of critically beloved and commercially overlooked releases on the tiny local indie label Twin/Tone, the band members were preparing their first LP for the Warner Bros.-backed major label Sire Records. Their songs were ecstatic, romantic, literary, and heartbreaking. Their brand was chaos: live shows that were transcendent or tragicomic depending on the drugs involved; albums that interpolated brilliant Stones-adjacent youth anthems and devastating country weepers with slapdash Kiss covers and improvised jams where no one played their actual instrument. Some wag once termed the Replacements “The little engine that could but didn't fuckin' feel like it.” But the band cared too much, and now the industry they collectively both mistrusted and fetishized was knocking at the door, proffering an opportunity. The resulting LP was “Tim,” which has been given the deluxe-reissue treatment, in the form of a five-disk set called “Tim: Let It Bleed Edition.” Some forty years later, the album feels like a five-alarm blaze, prophesying an era of corporate-driven consensus and the outsourcing of America's manufacturing sector.

;

;The Replacements' studied unprofessionalism had always been a point of pride, and possibly an aesthetic hedge. In a time of carefully crafted consumer products, here was a band so aggressively untamable that no one could ever accuse the group of selling out. In a world full of glossy fakery, its self-vandalizing, clown-school bloodletting was the genuine article. Or at least something genuine. And yet, unlike more avant-garde-influenced peers such as Black Flag and Sonic Youth, the Replacements made music that was a populist offshoot of influences like Rod Stewart and Marc Bolan, swaggering performers who had ridden meat-and-potatoes rock to global fame. However attitudinal the Replacements might have presented themselves, it didn't take a great deal of squinting to see the possibility of the band as arena fillers. The lead singer and songwriter Paul Westerberg was a punk-rock Jackson Browne, a pugilistic but ultimately heartsick poet with matinee-idol looks. The bassist, Tommy Stinson—thirteen when he joined the band, all of eighteen when “Tim” was tracked—appeared to be assembled in a rock-star factory, with the lank frame and chiselled beauty of a spare member of Duran Duran. Warner Bros. didn't sign the Replacements because the members oozed cachet. The company signed them because it saw dollar signs.

;

;Thus “Tim” commences with a binary choice. The opening track is called “Hold My Life,” and the decision is between fame—or at least a life-changing increase in notoriety—and something like a tactical retreat from the limelight. “Time for decision to be made,” Westerberg intones hoarsely over a driving pre-chorus: “Crack up in the sun / Or lose it in the shade.” A sentiment worthy of Jay Gatsby himself. By the end, the Replacements did a little bit of both.

;

;“Tim” is a great group of songs, possibly the best set that Westerberg has ever strung together for a single LP, but the revelation now is how powerfully the album captures the spiralling class anxieties of the era. As a hardscrabble collection of high-school dropouts and juvenile delinquents, the Replacements' four members came by their umbrage and fatalism organically. “Jail, death, or janitor,” was Westerberg's diagnosis for the range of plausible outcomes for the band members, and, indeed, in the group's early days, he served as a janitor in the Minnesota senator David Durenberger's office, an interloping pawn in the corridors of power. Class consciousness always figured into the Replacements' catalogue— including the looking-down-the-nose partygoers of “Color Me Impressed” and the golf-obsessed surgeon concerned with making his tee time on “Tommy Gets His Tonsils Out”—but on “Tim” that rage and resignation deepens. Likely because Westerberg has always nervously eschewed the significant political content of his own work, the press and biographers have been slow to characterize “Tim” as what it truly is: a great working-class treatise whose thematic and musical DNA runs through the Stones' “Beggars Banquet” and Bruce Springsteen's “Darkness on the Edge of Town.”

;

;Take, for instance, the joyously buoyant third track, “Kiss Me on the Bus,” an amorous flirtation and an echo of the Stones' “Factory Girl” that depicts two paramours who will need to make their emotional intentions clear within the insoluble strictures of public transportation. “Hurry, hurry!” Westerberg implores, while looking for a kiss. “Here comes my stop!” Or its transport-centric companion piece “Waitress in the Sky,” which on its surface is a mean-spirited broadside against flight attendants but was actually a blow-for-blow description of the kind of abuse that Westerberg's sister Julie experienced as a flight attendant. “A real union flight attendant, my oh my,” goes the sneering chorus. “You ain't nothing but a waitress in the sky.” The invocation of union allegiance as a source of ridicule is not coincidental. In 1981, Reagan had christened an era of scorched-earth anti-union policy by firing en masse ;the striking air-traffic-controllers' union; ;PATCO;. As safety nets for the working class and working poor were dismantled throughout the eighties and nineties, a fashionable stance among the emergent class of Milton Friedman- and ;Ayn Rand;-informed right-wingers was that labor organization was a hubristic overreach at best and a Communist plot at worst.

;

;On the enduring deep cut “Swingin Party,” a ballad partially about being economically outgunned in every social circumstance, and partially about the futile exertions of the under-credentialled, looking for work is presented as a zero-sum choice between abject poverty and a life of stultifying dullness: “Pound the prairie pavement / Losing proposition / Quittin' school and going to work / And never going fishing.” On the track “Little Mascara,” Westerberg demonstrates a trait that was glancingly rare among male songwriters of his era, the ability to write credibly about women. The story of a struggling young mother trapped in a loveless marriage and still dreaming of some way out, “Little Mascara” evokes Tennessee Williams in its depiction of a gifted individual circumscribed by their social context. When he sings “For the moon / You keep shootin' / Throw your rope up in the air / For the kid you stay together / You nap him and you slap him in a highchair,” the sublimated implications of multigenerational trauma are made explicit. On some level, and to varying degrees, all of the members of the Replacements had been born into a cycle of abuse, addiction, or depression. In “Little Mascara,” you wish the best for the mother, but your heart breaks for the baby. Fear and sadness will be the psychological foundation on which they'll have to build a life.

;
;
;

;Loudest of all, there's “Bastards of Young.” A generational howl of fury that commences with a literal scream. Here is the unvarnished offspring responding to a boomer generation that, having first controlled the cultural narrative, increasingly controls the political one. “God what a mess / On the ladder of success,” Westerberg contemptuously sings, taking sport at the rapidly receding myth of American upward mobility. “You take one step / And miss the whole first rung.” Like Randy Newman's “Louisiana 1927,” it is a perfect American song, capturing a time, place, and energy that resonates and reoccurs throughout history.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;To the band members' frustration, and also possibly their relief, “Tim” did not prove the kind of commercial breakthrough that would soon be achieved by REM The album's famous, strangely echoey production by the former Ramone Tommy Erdelyi was neither particularly radio-friendly nor organically punk-adjacent, and confused just about everyone. The front cover looked a little bit like L. Ron Hubbard's “;Dianetics;.” In a legendary bit of reckless self-sabotage, the band was so drunk and powerfully loud on a “Saturday Night Live” appearance that it remains unclear to this day whether the performance represented a shameful low or a resounding victory. “Tim” peaked at No. 183 on the charts, there being something faintly comical about even bothering to enter the ;Billboard; 200 at such a vaguely insulting level.

;
;
;

;And yet, on the occasion of the expansive new reissue, the cultural relevance of “Tim” is at an all-time high. “Bastards of Young” has become a calling card of sorts for misfit stories with a socioeconomic subtext, having been featured in Season 2 of the FX restaurant drama “;The Bear;.” The new box set is preoccupied with fixing perceived mistakes: a new mix, a new remaster, a counterfactual history of an awkwardly perfect album. There's lots of fun stuff on the updated version well worth hearing—scrappy tracks from a demo session with the band's spiritual mentor Alex Chilton, a typically wobbling and bracing 1986 live set from Chicago—but the perverse net effect is of taking a defensive stance to an LP that never truly needed defending. The new Ed Stasium remix is fine, but it was never really Erdelyi's heavy hand that prevented “Tim” from attaining its commercial aims. The original mix sounds no more gated or dated than “Born in the USA,” which never had any difficulty connecting to a mass audience. In the 2003 documentary “Come Feel Me Tremble,” Westerberg is asked his opinion of “Tim” and offers a typically gnomic and incisive verdict: “Coulda been.” Whether he is invoking ;Marlon Brando;'s “coulda been a contender” monologue from Elia Kazan's social-realist masterpiece “On the Waterfront” intentionally or just by osmosis doesn't really matter.

;

;
;

;After “Tim” was released, the members of the Replacements descended into interpersonal drama even more extreme than their accustomed standards. The guitarist Bob Stinson—Tommy's older brother—was dismissed for reasons of excess consumption and increasingly erratic behavior, which is a bit like censoring a sheep for being part of the herd. The longtime manager Peter Jesperson was jettisoned for thinking too small or thinking too big or maybe some combination of both. Remarkable music followed from there. “Pleased to Meet Me,” from 1987, a masterpiece recorded at Ardent Studios with the Memphis legend Jim Dickinson, further sharpened the band's sonics, centering Westerberg on guitar. “Don't Tell a Soul,” released in 1989, was the band's last big swing and featured its most commercial sound ever, a handful of good songs, and the closest thing the unit ever had to an actual hit, the keening “I'll Be You,” which peaked at No. 51. “I'll Be You” referenced the group's travails with typical self-deprecation. “A dream / too tired to come true / Left a rebel without a clue.” An opening tour for ;Tom Petty; and the Heartbreakers exposed them to a huge new audience, and it did not go well. Once it became clear that the Petty crowd was disinterested in both its music and its antics, the Replacements played worse and worse every night and tried to quit the tour, only for Petty himself to insist that the members honor their contracts. Petty later borrowed Westerberg's “rebel without a clue” formulation for “Into the Great Wide Open,” a tune about a talented but vain and erratic songwriter maladroitly navigating the music business. It became a smash.

;

;The Replacements—or at least Paul and Tommy backed by other musicians—staged a successful series of reunion dates between 2013 and 2015 where they were received by ecstatic festival crowds, singing along with every word. This seemed to spook the notoriously skittish Westerberg, who is a bit of a hermit, like his hero Ray Davies, back into hiding. Chris Mars, now a visual artist, prefers to keep his distance from his old mates. Bob Stinson died of organ failure in 1995, at the age of thirty-five. Tommy Stinson turned out to be the true lifer, doing time in Guns N' Roses and animating his own version of the Replacements' underdog ethos as front man of the roots-rock band Bash & Pop. Having started working as a literal child, he never stopped.

;

;“Tim” ends fittingly with the ritualistic holding pattern “Here Comes a Regular.” It's a barroom ballad that would fit as easily on Frank Sinatra's “In the Wee Small Hours” as it would on Merle Haggard's “Serving 190 Proof.” The song is distinguished by its epochal opening couplet: “A person can work up a mean, mean thirst / After a hard day of nothing much at all.” A final last call from a freighted time when both a band and a nation hung in the balance. ♦

;2023 年 9 月，Penguin Classics，一家著名的优雅亲英版本和便携式规范文本出版商 — Robert Fagles 翻译的 ;维吉尔的《埃涅阿斯纪》;、托马斯·哈代的“;市长卡斯特桥;”——发布了三本书，将“经典”一词推向新的、有争议的领域：“;X 战警;”、“;复仇者联盟;，”和“;神奇四侠;。”这些精美的精装书，其镀金边缘使它们看起来像莎士比亚的收藏版，大多以十九世纪六十年代的早期漫威故事为特色，即漫画爱好者有时称之为漫画的白银时代。他们加入企鹅卷“;黑豹，;” “;美国队长;”和“; 《超凡蜘蛛侠》;”，去年出版。那些认为经典是经过时间考验的巅峰之作、我们在学校读过的书籍或已故白人的作品的人可能会感到惊讶。 “只有当文明成熟时，经典才会出现，”一位死去的白人 TS 艾略特 (TS Eliot) 在 1944 年吟诵道。“它必须是成熟思想的作品。”企鹅出版社的第一部经典著作于 1946 年出版，是 EV Rieu 对 ;奥德赛;。钢铁侠和金刚狼是如何与奥德修斯和伊丽莎白·班纳特占据同一架子的？

;

;第一批“经典漫画”来自十九世纪四十年代，是经典小说，例如“;白鲸;”和“;艾芬豪;”重铸以漫画书的形式——久负盛名的知识产权，历史悠久，已经进入公共领域。那个时期的超级英雄漫画，后来被昵称为黄金时代，并没有标榜自己是经典的、文学的或经久不衰的：它们承诺的是刺激、悬疑和冒险，就在当下。第一批以漫威漫画为名的故事也是如此。 《超凡蜘蛛侠》第 1 期（1963 年 3 月）的封面承诺“两部精彩的长篇蜘蛛侠惊悚片！”它的醒目页面让该系列听起来像是与经典相反：“从来没有像蜘蛛侠这样的英雄！”

;

;不过很快，作家斯坦·李以及艺术家杰克·柯比和史蒂夫·迪特科开始即兴发挥著名文学的语言。 《复仇者联盟》第 1 期（1963 年 9 月）将其与洛基的对决称为“众星云集的长篇超级史诗系列的第一部，其中包括地球上最伟大的超级英雄！”你几乎会认为他们在写奥德修斯或贝奥武夫。 （事实上​​，他们写的都是关于托尔的故事，这位北欧传说中时而头脑迟钝的风暴之神，至今仍是漫威的一个主要角色。）“史诗”曾经是一个特定的文学评论术语，后来变成了任何超级英雄的漫画术语。跨越多个问题的故事。

;

;白银时代史诗也可能会呼应像 ;《伊利亚特》;。他们的插图任务将整个文化的价值观与值得尊敬、善意的对手进行斗争：正如荷马的赫克托王子努力保护特洛伊免受希腊人的掠夺一样，漫威的对手纳摩王子，潜艇水手，想要保卫他的亚特兰蒂斯王国免受人类的侵害入侵。 《伊利亚特》也介绍了继续进行进一步冒险的英雄队伍。其衍生作品包括维吉尔的《埃涅阿斯纪》和乔叟的“;特洛伊罗斯和 Criseyde;。”漫威的《复仇者联盟》本身就是一个衍生剧，是将钢铁侠、雷神托尔、绿巨人浩克等人聚集在一起的一种方式。它建立了他们共同的准神话世界，这使得漫威能够向喜爱现有英雄的读者推销新英雄。

;

;漫威粉丝不仅成为蜘蛛侠和雷神的粉丝，还成为漫威本身的粉丝。他们在漫画中、在一些元叙事中看到了创作者，这些元叙事的出现早于复活节彩蛋和斯坦·李在漫威电影中的客串。 “在这本史诗般的期刊中，惊喜接踵而至，”《神奇四侠》第 10 期的封面承诺，“因为你实际上在故事中遇到了李和卡比！！！”成人和青少年粉丝给编辑写了一些内容丰富的信件，这些信件被印在他们喜欢的漫画中。 “我们都 22 岁，我丈夫是大学毕业生，”《复仇者联盟》第 26 期的一位记者夸口道。他们可以加入 Merry Marvel Marching Society，这是一个授权粉丝俱乐部，拥有“TTB（泰坦尼克号忠实信徒）”和“KOF（火焰守护者）”等头衔。他们再次通过信件页面争夺漫威无奖奖，这是一份毫无价值的证书，颁发给那些解释了不一致、艺术家错误或编辑失误的粉丝。漫画正在成为不同意义上的经典：不是古老的，不一定是教育性的，而是冒险故事，为进一步的冒险奠定了基础，围绕这些故事可以形成强大的社区。;

;在他有影响力的书中“ ;想象的社区;，”本尼迪克特·安德森认为，共享阅读——报纸、小册子、小说——使现代欧洲国家成为可能。法国人用法语分享新闻和故事；英国人通过《伦敦新闻画报》、狄更斯的书和莎士比亚的崇拜走到了一起。当杰克·柯比 (Jack Kirby) 于 1970 年离开漫威，而李则于 1972 年辞去主编职务时，他们和他们的同事已经建立了一个微型国家：追随者精通秘密身份、地理和历史的语言。 ，渴望只有他们才能理解的新闻，并准备打造下一代。罗伊·托马斯 (Roy Thomas) 于 1966 年接手了《X 战警》和《复仇者联盟》，成为众多漫威粉丝中第一个转为职业选手的人，他们从小就阅读超级英雄漫画，然后受雇于学者们倾向于认为，白银时代漫画的持久力不是因为它们是永恒的，而是因为它们属于他们的时代。超人和蝙蝠侠等黄金时代的典范是具有传奇色彩的榜样，而白银时代的英雄则面临着普通人的问题。蜘蛛侠饰演的彼得·帕克总是需要钱，却很少得到女孩。 “为什么事情似乎总是不适合我？”他脱下戏服，沉思起来。 “为什么我好像会伤害别人？” X战警最初的青少年名单包括一个班级小丑（冰人）、一个自作聪明的人（杂技野兽）和一个冷酷负责的队长（独眼巨人），他不敢约他梦中的女孩。神奇四侠像一个可爱且知名的家庭一样生活、工作和争吵。读者——尤其是但不仅限于年轻人——可以从这些人物中看到他们自己的麻烦。这些漫画反映了六十年代（《黑豹》除外，他在七十年代获得了他的第一部多期漫画）。他们专注于地下核试验、反抗中的时髦青年以及流行的弗洛伊德精神分析。 “你可能要花几个月的时间来对我进行心理分析！我抽不出时间来！”陷入困境的史蒂夫·罗杰斯（美国队长的另一个自我）抱怨道。

;
;
;

;不过，仅靠及时性并不足以保持所有这些漫画都还活着，更不用说将它们引入经典了。 ;X-Men; 的销量太少，以至于漫威在 1970 年停止发布新的冒险系列。（该系列直到七十年代末和八十年代初才变得流行，甚至成为标志性的，并由一个由作家克里斯·克莱蒙特（Chris Claremont）、艺术家戴夫·科克鲁姆（Dave Cockrum）和约翰·伯恩（John Byrne），以及作家和编辑路易丝·西蒙森（Louise Simonson）和安·诺森蒂（Ann Nocenti）。）美国队长甚至不是来自白银时代；而是来自白银时代。卡比和乔·西蒙在四十年代创造了他，他在六十年代的冒险经历强调了他作为最伟大一代的继承人的地位，一个过时的孤独人。这些书中收录的最强漫画，不仅捕捉了时代，而且指向了时代。

;

;故事在一代代读者的整理、谈论、模仿、推荐中成为经典。在这种情况下，婴儿潮一代在它们首次亮相时阅读它们，X一代随着它们的续集长大，千禧一代通过漫威电影遇到它们。每一代的粉丝——最初的粉丝，越来越多的粉丝，以及如今的非二元粉丝——不仅找到了阅读漫画的新方式，还找到了使用漫画的新方式。卡农就是这样形成的。几十年来，业余爱好者和专业人士在哪些书重要以及为什么重要方面达成了共识，否则他们喜欢争论这个问题，而我们就得遵循这些论点。当拥有出版、教学和编辑权力的一代人与前一代人出现分歧时，经典就会兴衰，获得作品，也会失去其他作品。

;
;
;

;对于现在的一代人来说主管文学出版，漫画可以成为经典。回想起来，我们可以看到为什么这些标题和这些具体问题（例如《神奇四侠》第 48-50 期，但不是第 43 期）很重要。 《蜘蛛侠》、《神奇四侠》和其他漫画的“经典”期代表了连载漫画中作为视觉艺术或故事转折点的高潮——而且往往两者兼而有之。对粉丝来说重要的故事可能比封面吹捧的故事具有更低、更不明显的风险。我们知道变形的斯库鲁人不会毁灭地球，否则就不会有下一个问题。但镭射眼会邀请漫威女孩出去吗？里德·理查兹会和他的女朋友苏·斯托姆结婚吗？直到我们阅读之后我们才知道。与其说这是冒险故事的逻辑，不如说是漫威也出版的浪漫漫画的逻辑。 （参见模特米莉。）道格拉斯·沃尔克（Douglas Wolk）阅读了 1961 年至 2017 年间出版的所有漫威漫画，为他的书《;所有Marvels;”（2021）解释说，漫威六十年代的标志性作品通过“将怪物漫画、浪漫漫画和幽默漫画吸收到超级英雄漫画中”而得以激增。冒险，但也有焦虑；打斗，还有讽刺和肥皂剧。

;黑豹进入这一经典的旅程后来开始，并走了一条不同的道路。企鹅出版社的版本于 1966 年开始，瓦坎达是一个“位于赤道非洲中心”的科技乌托邦，在《神奇四侠》漫画中首次出现。然后它跳到 1973 年至 1976 年间出版的 16 部漫画。所有漫画都是由唐·麦格雷戈 (Don McGregor) 编写的，他发展了后来的编剧和编剧将使用的神话故事——《基尔芒格》、《勇士瀑布》、《皇家宫殿》。 （“当我被从黑豹上取下来时，”麦格雷戈说，“有人告诉我这是因为我太接近黑人的经历了。我看着我的白手。”）麦格雷戈和铅笔师比利·格雷厄姆塑造了一个战士——在瓦坎达之外可以成为超级英雄的国王，但在家里却必须学会成为果断的统治者和浪漫的男主角。瓦坎达与漫威宇宙的其他部分存在一定距离——无论是概念上还是实际上都是另一个国家。它必须等上几十年，并得到好莱坞的推动，才能成为不仅仅是一种崇拜的经典。

;

;当散文作家在十八世纪的文学地位上升时，诗歌爱好者认为中等粗俗。这种态度可能需要数年时间才能改变，而漫画是一个特殊的出发点：它们不仅是一种文本媒介，而且是一种视觉媒介。柯比（Kirby）或他的《美国队长》继任者吉姆·斯特兰科（Jim Steranko）创作的一部顶级漫画几乎不需要言语。您只需观察角色的行为和反应即可了解故事情节。值得庆幸的是，企鹅出版社对这些图像进行了公正的处理。他们在厚厚的白纸上用明亮、平坦、彩色的墨水再现了六十年代的漫画——与旧新闻纸上使用的点式处理不同，但也许更真实地体现了他们大胆、追逐刺激的精神。

;

;; 《神奇四侠》年度第 6 期（1968 年），整页展示了一个橙黑相间的物体通过洋红色新星爆发向后坠落。 《火炬》讲述了他“无助地被抛入太空……”的故事。 。 。就像一群无力的布娃娃！”在前景中，里德·理查兹痛苦地尖叫；我们只能看到他的脸，其他部分都在画面之外。他像巴洛克画作中的伊卡洛斯一样倒下了。在整个卡比的故事中，尤其是在《神奇四侠》中，太空时代的英雄们横扫梦幻般的背景：星星、星云，甚至还有手绘人物叠加的黑白照片拼贴。卡比工艺的顶峰在墨水师乔·辛诺特和一位未注明出处的调色师（可能是玛丽·塞维林）的协助下，出现得稍早一些，在吞噬者的奇观中——一个巨大的、经常戴着紫色头盔、满嘴紫色散文的坏人。他是一名太空旅行者，也是一个奇观，对人类的苦难漠不关心。后来的漫画家还没有能与他相媲美。

;

;李、柯比和迪特科现在都已经死了。顾名思义，经典作品已经过时了，而且这些书籍的某些部分已经过时了。尽管有石头人的例子，但传统上丑陋或明显毁容的角色通常都是恶棍，从伤痕累累、复仇心切的九头蛇夫人到又大又圆、闷闷不乐的斑点。解决民权斗争的尝试因温和的中间主义而受到影响。恶棍们无缘无故地解释他们的计划；一切都带有感叹号。女性（或“女孩”，如隐形女孩）拥有女性的力量，例如收缩、间谍或隐形；很少有两个或两个以上的女性交谈。有些情节毫无意义。但这些漫画与那个时代的几乎所有其他流行文化产品以及我们自己的许多流行文化产品都有这样的缺陷。我们一直在阅读它们，寻找它们的突出之处。

;

;白银时代的漫威意味着情感（《X战警》中独眼巨人和漫威女孩的相思；《神奇四侠》中石头人的抑郁）和奇观：一个令人惊叹的世界具有新视角的眼睛、闪亮的星际小玩意和永远在行动的英雄。但在漫画中，这个世界在没有竞争的情况下能够为更多的读者做更多的事情。在现代数字图形之前，在《星球大战》之前，在电子游戏之前，只有在四色漫画的页面中，这样的宇宙事迹和超人壮举才能找到合适的视觉形式。六十年代电影的特效在今天看起来很俗气，但六十年代早期漫画的视觉效果在现代屏幕上却出奇地好。

;

;对于现代超级英雄漫画来说，这是一个问题。长期的漫威角色现在适合史诗电影，从“;X战警;”到“< a href="https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-comic-book-aesthetic-comes-of-age-in-across-the-spider-verse">;蜘蛛侠：跨越蜘蛛侠宇宙;”。就像今天正在被重新发明的其他经典故事一样，它们至少有时会出现在电视上（“女绿巨人”、“惊奇女士”），并且它们激发了文学小说的灵感，来自迈克尔·查邦（Michael Chabon）的普利策奖获奖作品《<数据提供》 -url="https://www.amazon.com/Amazing-Adventures-Kavalier-bonus-content-ebook/dp/B0070O5F4U" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink"," outgoingURL”：“https://www.amazon.com/Amazing-Adventures-Kavalier-bonus-content-ebook/dp/B0070O5F4U”}" href="https://www.amazon.com/Amazing-Adventures- Kavalier-bonus-content-ebook/dp/B0070O5F4U" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">;The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier and Clay;” (2000) 到鲍勃·普罗尔 (Bob Proehl) 的关于超能力变种人的被忽视且令人心碎的小说， “;无人之人;”和“;The Somebody People;”（2019-20）。简而言之，当今的超级英雄漫画存在竞争。尽管更广泛的媒体表现良好 - 请参阅 ;Alison Bechdel; 的切片生活图文回忆录或雷娜·特尔格迈尔 (Raina Telgemeier) 的儿童漫画——装订连续剧现在面临着身份危机。药店不再出售它们；只有专门的漫画店才有。 （您也可以付费在线阅读。） 1991 年出版的《X 战警》是有史以来最畅销的漫画书，其销售数字可能是无与伦比的。电子游戏或许能更好地满足我们的幻想； Netflix 更易于导航。

;超级英雄漫画仍然有关于不断发展的角色和他们共享的世界的持续故事。对于那些想要比好莱坞所能提供的更多故事或不同故事的粉丝来说，它们是一个社区所在地，并且它们为新艺术家、新作家和老团队中的新英雄提供了空间。因为它们的制作成本比电影或电视便宜得多，所以有时会让编剧承担更多的风险。在漫威电影或白银时代漫画中，你不会发现年轻、明确的跨性别者之间的友谊占据中心舞台，但你可以在漫威的;新变种人;（2020）的美丽而复杂的问题中看到这一点。 -23)，由维塔·阿亚拉 (Vita Ayala) 撰写，随后由查理·简·安德斯 (Charlie Jane Anders) 撰写。

;
;
;

;艾略特认为，真正的民族经典必须展示“全方位的感觉”并引起“所有阶级和条件的人的反应”。总而言之，漫威宇宙可以说已经很接近了。沃尔克称其为“一座位于当代文化中心的山”，“从未停止生长”。但那些离开、放弃或离开的读者将不得不被新一代所取代。只要能赚钱，超级电影可能会不断出现，档案版也可能会不断推出。然而，如果漫画书店里没有新人，也没有吸引新读者的故事，漫威漫画就有可能成为马克·吐温所说的经典：“每个人都想读，但没有人愿意读的东西。”就连吞噬者也不希望这样。 ♦
